PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Ernest C. Fletcher
Address: Box 89, Kincaid, Sask.
Birthplace: Worcester, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1913
Where did you set up housekeeping? Hazenmere, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Duff, Sask.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 2
How far was it to your nearest store? 19 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Much the same as now

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? True Rose
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 3-25
How much did you use graham flour? Not often
Whole wheat flour? Occasionally
Was flour milled locally? Sometimes
How far away? 10 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 90¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes
Whole Wheat? Some
Farina? Yes
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes
How did you grind it? Usually a neighbour's grinder
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Ernest C. Fletcher (Mrs. Ernest C.)

Address: Box 89, Kincaid, 1913

Birthplace: Woburn, England

Came out in 1905

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1913

Where had you been living before that? Hayman M.R., S.A.S.R.

For how many people did you prepare meals? 2

How far was it to your nearest store? 1 mile

How often could a visit be made to the store? Usually, twice a week

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand or white flour did you use in the early years? None

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 3-25¢

How much did you use graham flour? 100 lbs.

Whole wheat flour? 100 lbs.

Was flour milled locally? Yes

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 90¢

What other grain products did you use?

Cornmeal? 100 lbs.

Wheat Wheat? 100 lbs.

Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes

How did you grind it? Normally a neighbour's grinders
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 60¢

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edwards

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? all sizes

At what price? (not remembered) but cheaper than now

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Cow

Butter? Our own

Eggs? Own

What was the price of butter? 25¢

Did you pick eggs for hens? Yes

Water glass for salt?

Did you make butter? Yes

What kind of cheese? Sometimes Cottage Cheese

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef & Pork

Chicken

How did you get fresh meat? Panned our own

How often did you get fresh meat? During Winter

How did you preserve meat? Canned & Salted

Beef

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Later yes

If so what year was it organized? about 1912

Did you use game? Yes

What kinds? Prairie Chicken or Rabbit

For how long? When we could get them

What part did fish play in the family diet? Very little

Has the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned

Kinds? Usually Salmon or Herring
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy? (to nearest $1.00) $6.25

What was the price for a ten pound sack of this sugar? $1.25

That brand of molasses syrup did you use? All States

That size of tin or syrup did you usually buy? All States

At what price? (Price of tin included)

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of cream milk in the early days?

Butter? Yes

That was the price of butter? $2.00

Did you pick eggs for hens? Yes

Did you make butter? Yes

What kind of cheese? Sweet Curd Cottage Cheese

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years?

How did you get fresh meat? Beef

How often did you get fresh meat? Weekly

How did you preserve meat? Salted

Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? No

If so what was it organized? No

Did you use films? Yes

For how long? 1912

What part did fish play in the family diet? Very little

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned

Was the fish whole, cut up, or filleted? Filleted

Was the fish salted, curried, or seasoned? Seasoned

Was the fish cooked? Yes

Was the fish eaten? Yes
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Lipton? Other at what price? 75¢
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground
Price? about 4.5¢ That other beverages were used? Cocoa

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 30¢
Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes
If not, where from? Out of state
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1926 Carrots 1926 Onions 1926
Turnips 1926 Beets 1926
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 lbs.
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box
What weight? 50 lbs How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? 40¢
What was the price of prunes?

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?
There were shipped in later years.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Peas? Corn? Beans? Yes
Other foods? Wild fruit, raspberries, blackberries, currants, blueberries, etc.
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1926
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1926
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1926
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes
To what extent? Can all my own fruit & chicken
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes in early years not now.

13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made our own.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes... used ashes?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal.

Where did you get your fuel? In the Bluff, around town.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

After moving to the South West we burned all coal. Now both coal & fuel oil is used. Also Propane & Electric stoves in town.

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Most purchases were weighed out in paper bags.

Celophane did not come till the 30's or 40's.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge, toast, tea, jam.

Dinner: Meat, vegetables, pudding.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? ...................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

There would be Chicken & Beef,
vegetables, home grown,
relish & English plum pudding,
& mince-pie.

We were English you see.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, but living was reduced to bare necessities in the Drought Period of 1930's.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Simpler in 1908.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Still grow much of our own vegetables etc. I now rely on prepared foods more.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above; quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Not so many luxuries, but the fare was good & wholesome.
21. Start this year to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and homemade (as much as possible).

Still grow our own if we can.

Don't rely on prepared foods alone.
